metadata.title: Detailed surface study of adsorbed nickel on Al12N12 nano-cage

sections.text:
Detailed surface study of adsorbed nickel on Al12N12 nano-cage Ali Shokuhi Rad, Khurshid Ayub PII: S0040-6090(16)30232-2 DOI: doi: 10.1016/j.tsf.2016.05.055 Reference: TSF 35238 To appear in: Thin Solid Films Received date: 6 January 2016 Revised date: 31 May 2016 Accepted date: 31 May 2016
Please cite this article as: Ali Shokuhi Rad, Khurshid Ayub, Detailed surface study of adsorbed nickel on Al12N12 nano-cage, Thin Solid Films (2016), doi: 10.1016/j.tsf.2016.05.055

The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Detailed surface study of adsorbed nickel on Al12N12 nano-cage
Ali Shokuhi Rad *a , Khurshid Ayub b
a Department of Chemical Engineering, Qaemshahr Branch, Islamic Azad University,
Qaemshahr, Iran
b Department of Chemistry, COMSATS Institute of Information Technology, University
Road, Tobe Camp, 22060 Abbottabad, Pakistan
*E-mail: a.shokuhi@gmail.com , a.shokuhi@qaemiau.ac.ir
Tel: 0098-9112134588
Fax: 0098-11132367735
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Abstract The geometries and electronic structures of Ni-adsorbed Al12N12 (AlN) nano-cage are studied by density functional theory. A number of different structures varying in the position and orientation of nickel on the surface of the nano-cage are studied. Binding energies, band structures, total density of states, natural bond orbital charges, and electron density differences of Ni-adsorbed Al12N12 nano-cage were calculated, and analyzed in comparison with pure AlN nano-cage. The adsorption energies are in the range of (-110) ~ (-113) kcal mol -1 for three adsorption sites (P1-P3), and about -86 kcal mol -1 for P4. High binding energies for these geometries suggest strong chemisorption of nickel on AlN nano-cage. Moreover, dissociation of Al-N bond is observed concurrent with the formation of Ni-Al and Ni-N bonds when the Ni atom is adsorbed on the nano-cage. Results from the calculations also reveal that there is significant charge transfer from the nano-cage to the metal atom which changes the location of HOMO (highest occupied molecular orbital) and LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) resulting reduces in the Egap (EHOMO-ELUMO). The HOMO-LUMO gap for P4 geometry is 1.79 eV which is much lower than the band gap for pure AlN nano-cage (3.93 eV). The band gap for P1, P2 and P3 geometries are 2.90, 2.79 and 3.18 eV, respectively. The decrease in band gap is attributed to the push of outer d electrons of the transition metals to become more diffuse like. The HOMOs in all geometries have densities on Ni atom whereas the densities in LUMO are distributed on the entire skeleton. The results revealed that Ni adsorption provides N-type conduction which makes it an ideal adsorbent for practical applications in magnetism, catalysis and other areas. Reactivity descriptors indicate an increase in electrophilic character of Ni-adsorbed nano-cages compared to pure AlN nano-cage. The electron affinity and softness are highest for P4 geometry whereas the lowest ionization potential and hardness are calculated for P4. Key words: Nano-cage, Al12N12, Nickel, density functional theory, adsorption
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The invention of carbon nanotubes by Ijimia sparked fast progress in the field of nano-scale carbon materials [1]. In recent years, numerous theoretical reports have appeared on doped nanostructures for their geometries, electronic properties and sensing abilities for different analytes [2-9]. For example, [5] Al-doped graphene is shown as an excellent adsorbent for acetyl halide molecules. Moreover, the application of Al-doped graphene as sensor for some ether molecules is also demonstrated [6]. The Al-doped graphene has high sensing ability for the ether molecules. Al-doped graphene has also been investigated theoretically for its sensing ability for NO2 and N2O [7] CO, CO2, H2O [8] and some halomethane molecules [9]. Besides metal doping, metal adsorption of nanostructures [10-11] also imparts very interesting geometric and electronic properties. In our previous study [10], we have shown enhanced adsorption of NO on platinum adsorbed graphene (PtG), compared to very weak adsorption on pristine graphene. In another report, Pt-adsorbed graphene is also shown as an ideal adsorbent for C2H2 and C2H4 molecules [11]. Motivated by the applications of carbon nano-tube, graphene and C60 in different areas, extensive research has been carried out to synthesize spherical or tubular fullerenes like structures of different non-carbon inorganic materials. A few examples of this type include boron nitride (BN)[12], silica (SiO2)[13] aluminum nitride (AlN)[14] and coaxial cubic aluminum nitride–boron nitride composite nanotubes [15]. Aluminum nitride (AlN) is very fascinating combination of physical and electronic properties, and can exist in planer, tubular or spherical forms. All members of its family are well-known as large band-gap semiconductor material having many superior properties. Moreover, AlN finds applications in electronic packaging material, optical disks and lithographic photo masks [16-18]. AlN is stable at high temperatures with substantial thermal conductivity, small thermal expansion, and considerable response to gases and chemicals
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
[19]. Recently, AlN has received widespread concentration owing to its potential use as a diluted magnetic semiconductor with possible use in the field of spin transport electronics. Oku et al [20] reported the synthesis of spherical non-carbon B12N12, and the structure was detected by laser desorption time-of-flight mass spectrometry. Later, the stability of (AlN)n nanostructures was discussed using ab-initio calculations. The structure as well as steadiness of different structures of (AlN)n(n = 2–41) were investigated [21]. Based on their report, Al12N12 is the most stable cluster in this family, a perfect inorganic fullerene-like cage. In our recent study [22], we investigated on the adsorption property of guanine molecule on the surface of four nano-cages using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. We found that despite AlN has the highest adsorption energy; however, BN and BP show more changes in electronic property upon adsorption of guanine.
Besides AlN, metal-AlN nano-materials have potential applicants in catalysis, optical and magnetic devices. There are several first-principles theoretical reports on metal interaction with AlN and GaN [23-28]. For example, Zhang et al. [23] used DFT to search on the probability of bare- and Ni-adsorbed AlN nano-cages for hydrogen storage. They found that in bare AlN, each Al atom is able of adsorb one H2 whereas the Ni atom in Ni-AlN can adsorb up to three hydrogen molecules. Panaet. al. [24] investigated the effect of Si-doping onAlN films. They showed that Si is a potential nonmagnetic dopant for preparing diluted magnetic semiconductor films. In another theoretical study, Cui et al [28] have shown that Cr atom has strong tendency to segregate to form Cr-N-Cr bonded embedded clusters. There is no detailed report in the literature on the adsorption of metal on Al12N12, an important spherical member of AlN family. Geometric, energetic and electronic parameters including binding energy calculation, bond lengths, charge analysis, dipole moments, and band gaps of the Ni adsorbed Al12N12 nano-cage at different adsorption positions have been investigated through density functional theory methods.

D M
AN U

sections.heading: 2. Computational methods
sections.text:
Geometry optimizations and density of states (DOS) analysis were performed for different Ni/ AlN complexes and compared with pure AlN (see Figs. 1 and 2). All calculations were performed by using B3LYP method of DFT with 6-31G (d,p) basis set, as implemented in the Gaussian 09 suite of program [29]. B3LYP is a popular functional that has been commonly used for nanotube structures [30]. We have studied the influence of Ni- decorating on the electronic properties of Al12N12 (in following, denoted as AlN for simplicity). After the optimization, the electronic parameters were calculated for the relaxed structures. The adsorption energy of Ni on the AlN at different positions is specified through as follow: Eads= EAlN-Ni- (EAlN + ENi) (1) Where EAlN-Ni is the total (electronic) energy of AlN interacting with the Ni and EAlN is total energy of isolated AlN, and ENi is the total energy of an isolated Ni. 3. Results and discussion
Figure 1. Relaxed structure of AlN (left) and it's MEP (right). A1 and A2 correspond to the four-and six- membered rings, d1 is the bond length of Al-N (between A1 and A2 rings), and d2 is the bond length of Al-N (between two A2 rings)
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
The optimized geometry of AlN nano-cage (Figure 1) has four and six membered rings, and the geometric parameters correlate nicely with the literature values [31]. A number of different orientations of Ni on the surface of AlN nano-cage are explored in order to find the minimum energy structure. A nickel atom can be adsorbed on the surface of AlN nano-cage either on a bond, a ring or an atom. For orientation on an atom, the interaction of nickel atom with Al (M@Al) and N (M@N) is studied. The AlN nano-cage has four and six membered rings, the nickel atom was studied on both four (M@r4) and six (M@r6) membered rings. Moreover, the nickel atom was also studied on bond (d2) joining two six membered ring (M@b66) or a six and four membered ring (M@b64) (d1). With these six input geometries, only four different geometries were optimized; M@b64, M@b66, M@r4 and M@r6. For simplicity,M@b64, M@b66, M@r4 and M@r6 are designated as P1, P2, P3 and P4 (shown in Figure 2 for top and side views).
The most stable orientation of Ni on the surface of AlN nano-cage is on the bond between the rings (d1 and d2). The interaction energies for the adsorption of Ni on AlN nano-cage in P1
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
and P2 orientation are 113.7 and 113.6 kcal mol -1 . The high interaction energies are indicative of chemisorption of nickel on the surface of AlN nano-cage. Equal interaction energies in P1 and P2 orientation clearly illustrate that the effect of ring size of the AlNnanocage is negligible. The interaction energy in P3 geometry is relatively less (110.2 kcal mol -1 ). The interaction energy in P4 is reduced to -86.7 kcal mol -1 , The geometries of P1-P4 are analyzed to rationalize the difference in interaction energies. Our calculated adsorption energies of Ni on AlN for P1, P2, and P3 all are a bit more than those of calculated for Ni adsorption on AlP in the same positions ( -102.7 kcal mol -1 for P1, -99.4 kcal mol -1 for P2, - 108.5 kcal mol -1 for P3) and also significantly lower than that of calculated for P4 (-136.7 kcal mol -1 ) reported by us [32]. Also the value of adsorption energy in each position is grater than that is calculated for adsorption of Ni on the best position of GaN surface ( -103.1 kcal mol -1 ) [25] and also are significantly higher compared to that reported in the best position for Ni adsorption on AlN (-52.2 kcal mol -1 ) by using the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerh of correlation functional [23]. In P1, the nickel atom is at a distance of 1.54Å from the nano-cage (as shown in Figure 2) whereas in P2, nickel is at a distance of 1.64 Å. The shorter distance of nickel to the nanocage in P1 results in the larger N-Ni-Al bond angle (72.60˚) compared to P2 (61.42˚). The close proximity of nickel to the nano-cage in P1 also causes the four membered ring to change into an envelope like five membered ring which causes the Al-N bond (d1) to elongate to 2.35Å. This conversion of four membered ring to a five membered ring releases some strain (more stabilized) but at the same time, elongation of Al-N bond (d1) increases the energy of the system, a nullifying effect. On the other hand, change in the bond lengths of the nano-cage in P2 is relatively less compared to P1. Interestingly, the distance of Ni-AlN in all positions is much shorter than what is calculated for the distance of Ni-GaN [25]. The Al-N bonds are 1.87Å and 2.03Å for d1 and d2, respectively.The Ni-N and Ni-Al bond distances in
AC C
EP
TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
P1 are 1.73Å and 2.19Å respectively whereas the corresponding bond distances in P2 are 1.73Å and 2.17Å. The relatively short bonds of nickel with the nano-cage in P2 are indicative of stronger interaction of nickel with the nano-cage. In P3, the Ni atom is oriented on a four membered ring (no direct on a bond) which results in very little change in d1 and d2 when compared with P1 and P2 geometries. The nickel atom is not oriented in the middle of the four membered ring but displaced towards on side to make a pyramid with one nitrogen and two aluminum atoms. N-Ni bond distances are 1.72Å and 2.97Å whereas Al-Ni bond distances are 2.39Å and 2.37Å. N-Al-N bond angles are 54.22 and 55.09 degrees whereas the Al-Ni-Al and N-Ni-N bond angles are 65.30 and 68.64 degrees, respectively. Quite similar to P3, the Ni atom in P4 is also unsymmetrically oriented however in this case the binding of Ni is preferred through two nitrogen atoms and one aluminum atom. The N-Ni bond distances are 2.00Å, 2.02Å and 2.70Å whereas the Ni-Al bond distances are 2.07Å, 2.45Å and 2.49 Å. The interaction distances of Ni with nitrogen and aluminum in P4 are much longer than in P3 which results in lower interaction energies.

The dipole moments, natural bond orbital (NBO) charges and molecular electrostatic potential (MEP) are also studied for the Ni adsorbed AlN, and compared with the free AlN
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
nano-cage. Adsorption of a nickel atom on the nano-cages has significant effect on the dipole moment. The dipole moment of AlN nano-cage is essentially zero. After complexation, dipole moments increase significantly. The dipole moments are highest for P2 and P3 geometries (2.76 D, see Table 1) followed by P1 (2.07 D). The lowest dipole moment is calculated for P4. For geometries P1-P3, the dipole moment is pointed towards the nickel atom whereas the dipole moment vector points away from nickel in P4. This change in behavior in P4 is probably due to the difference in electronic structure around nickel. For P1P3, the nickel atom is attached to only one nitrogen atom whereas in P4, the nickel is attached through two nitrogen atoms (equidistant) whereas the third nitrogen is at relatively large distance.The nickel atom in P4 is relatively less positive because of coordination of multiple nitrogen atoms. This change in electronic structure causes a flip in the direction of dipole moment. Moreover, this change in electronic structure is also reflected by NBO charge analysis. For P1-P3, the QNBO is 0.46-0.47 whereas in P4, QNBOon nickel is 0.35. Moreover, this difference in electronic structure of nickel in P4 is also reflected in the MEP (shown in Figure 3). In MEP map, potential increases in the order red < orange < yellow < green < blue. For AlN nano-cages, Al is positively charged (blue color) whereas the nitrogen is negatively charged. The negative charge on N in the nano-cage is moderate (yellow color). On interaction of Ni with the nano-cage, small changes are observed in the MEP. The nickel atom gets positive potential.For P1-P3, high potential is observed at Nickel whereas in P4, the nickel terminus has low potential (green color)
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Fig. 3. The MEP of different systems In order to get detailed insight into the electronic changes caused by adsorption of Ni on the AlN nano-cage, frontier molecular orbitals are analyzed before and after adsorption. The frontier molecular orbitals are given in Figure 5 whereas the energies of highest occupied molecular orbital (EHOMO), lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (ELUMO), Fermi level (EFL), HOMO-LUMO gap (Eg) for different systems are given in Table 2.
AC C
EP

D M

IP T
AlN-Ni (P2) -5.19 -3.79 -2.40 2.79 AlN-Ni (P3) -5.64 -4.05 -2.46 3.18 AlN-Ni (P4) -4.39 -3.53 -2.68 1.79
Fig. 4. The HOMO-LUMO outlook of free AlN and Ni-adsorbed modes at different positions
AlN nano-cage is an insulator due to the large gap between HOMO and LUMO. Energies of HOMO and LUMO of AlNnano-cage are -6.47 and -2.54 eV with a Fermi level of -4.50 eV. The band gap in AlN is 3.93 eV. The HOMO in AlN nano-cage is mostly located on nitrogen atoms whereas the LUMO has density uniformly distributed on all atoms. The large band gap limits the application of these nano-cages in the electronic devices. Therefore, dopants are introduced to decrease the HOMO-LUMO gap. We have explored the electronic properties of Ni adsorbed AlN nano-cages to realize the effect of doping on the band gap. Nickel is a metal for which HOMO-LUMO gap is merely 0.22 eV. The energies of HOMO and LUMO of metal are -5.82 and -5.6 eV. Upon interaction of Ni with AlN nano-cage, significant changes are observed not only in the energies of HOMO and LUMO but also in their densities. The HOMO-LUMO gap is reduced for all geometries of nickel adsorbed AlN
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
nano-cages (P1-P4). Moreover, the HOMO in all metal adsorbed AlN nano-cages is located on the metal atom. However, the LUMO has density spread over the entire skeleton. For P1, energy of HOMO is affected much significantly than the energy of LUMO. The energy of HOMO in P1 is -5.35 eV compared to -6.47 eV in pure AlN nano-cage. The energy of LUMO, on the other hand, is slightly increased to 2.45 eV from -2.54 eV for pristine AlN nano-cage. The pronounced increase in the energy of HOMO decreases the HOMO-LUMO energy gap from 3.93 eV to 2.90 eV. A similar but relatively more pronounced effect is observed for P2 geometry. The energies of HOMO and LUMO are increased to -5.19 eV and -2.40 eV, respectively. The HOMO-LUMO gap in P2 is further decreased to 2.79 eV. P3 and P4 are the geometries where Ni atom is located on a hollow position above a ring, and coordinates to more than two atoms therefore, it is expected that the electronic properties of these geometries will be different than P1 and P2 where the Ni atom is situated above a bond and only two atoms of the nano-cage interact with Ni. The HOMO energy in P3 is not increased as significantly as in P1 and P2 which results in relatively higher HOMO-LUMO gap (3.18) compared to P1 and P2. Quite contrary to P3, the HOMO-LUMO gap in P4 is significantly reduced (1.79 eV). The HOMO energy in P4 is increases (compared to AlNnano-cage) whereas the LUMO energy decreases which results in decrease in HOMOLUMO gap. The doping of AlNnano-cage with a nickel atom significantly reduces the band gap. The density of states (DOS) are plotted to understand this interesting phenomenon.The density of states of nano-cage is compared in its pure and nickel adsorbed geometries (P1-P4) (see Figure 5). By comparison, it is observed that doping of a nickel atom causes significant shift of the occupied orbitals of AlN nano-cage to high energy levels and the newly formed HOMOs lie between the original HOMO and LUMO of AlN nano-cage. These energy states appear near Fermi level for all complexes which cause decrease in Eg values. These doped
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
nano-cages behave like n-type semiconductors. The newly formed HOMO originates from the nickel atom (see Figure 4). The highest change in Eg is observed for P4 (ΔEg = 2.14 eV) followed by P2 (ΔEg = 1.14 eV). The decrease in the band gap is mainly due to the increase in the energy of HOMO arising from interaction of lone pair of electrons of nitrogen with the metal atom. Lone pairs of nitrogen in the nano-cage push the outer d electrons of Ni to become diffuse excess electron which increases the energy level of the newly formed HOMO. However, no such type of phenomenon is observed for LUMO. The LUMO of the nano-cage is acceptor for electron and it might take electrons from the nickel atom. Therefore the density is expected to reside mostly on the nano-cage skeleton. Indeed, this has been observed. The P4 orientation has more pronounced effect on the HOMO-LUMO gap which is mainly due to the presence of two coordinating nitrogen atoms to the nickel atom. In P1-P3 orientations, only one nitrogen atom interacts with the metal center therefore, one should expect comparable effect on the HOMO energies. Indeed this is the case for P1 and P2. Another factor contributing to the increase in the energy of HOMO is the strength of the interaction of nitrogen with the metal atom. In P3, the interaction of nitrogen is relatively weak compared to P1 and P2; therefore, a relatively less significant effect is expected. Change is Eg for metal doped AlN nano-cage is expected to cause significant changes in electrical conductivity because the electrical conductivity of bulk material is mainly determined by Eg (for bulk materials). Relationship between conductivity and Eg can be given by the following equation [33]: σ α exp(Eg/kT) (2)
where it can be seen clearly that a small decrease in Eg leads to significantly higher electrical conductivities
The global indices of reactivity for AlNnano-cage and nickel adsorbed AlN nano-cages (P1P4) are given in Table 3. The stability and reactivity of a molecule is determined through the global indices of reactivity. The ionization potential and electron affinities can be estimated from the energies of HOMO and LUMO, respectively. The electrophilicity concept was
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
stated in 1999 by Parr et al. [34]. Chemical potential (µ) is defined based the subsequent equation [35]: µ=−(EHOMO+ELUMO)/2 (3) where EHOMO is the energy of HOMO and ELUMO is the energy of LUMO. In addition, hardness (ŋ) can be calculated using the Koopmans’ theorem [35] as: ŋ = (ELUMO – EHOMO)/2 (4) Softness (S) [35] and electrophilicity(ω) [35] are explained as the subsequent equations, respectively. S= 1/2 ŋ (5) ω= µ 2 /2 ŋ (6) The ionization potential decreases when nickel is adsorbed on AlN nano-cage. The ionization potentials of P1, P2, P3 and P4 are 5.35 eV, 5.19 eV, 5.64 eV and 4.39 eV. The ionization potential is the lowest for P4 whereas the electron affinity is the highest for P4. The electron affinities of nickel adsorbed AlNnano-cages are also lower than the pure AlNnano-cage except P4. Interestingly, the hardness for the nano-cages decreases on adsorption with nickel. AlN has the hardness value of 1.96 eV which decreases significantly to 1.45 eV, 1.40 eV and 1.59 eV for P1, P2 and P3, respectively. The lowest hardness (0.90 eV) is calculated for P4. The hardness depends on the difference of ionization potential and electron affinities therefore, the lowest hardness is expected for P4. Since softness is contrary to the hardness therefore, nickel adsorbed AlN complex, P4, is expected to be the softest complex. Decrease in hardness and increase in softness of P4 illustrates its reactive nature. The complex P4 is relatively more electrophilic than AlN or nickel adsorbed AlN (P1, P2 and P3). Electrophilicity of the AlN nano-cage increases on complexation with nickel atom.
The chemical potential increases for all nano-cages on complexation with nickel. For AlN, chemical potential is -4.5 eV which increases to -3.90 eV for P1. Similarly, the chemical
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC
R
IP T
potentials of P2, P3 and P4 increase to -3.79 eV, -4.05 eV and -3.53 eV, respectively. The highest change in chemical potential is observed for P4.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The large band gap limits the application of AlN in the electronic devices; therefore, we engineered the electronic properties by introducing Ni- dopant. Geometries, electronic properties and quantum mechanical descriptors have been calculated for a number of orientation of nickel dopant on the surface of AlN nano-cage. Our calculations show that the transition metal atoms (Ni) can form stable structures with the Al12N12 nano-cage at different positions. The adsorption energies are in the range of (-110) ~ (-113) kcal mol -1 for three adsorption sites (P1-P3), and about -86 kcal mol -1 for P4. High binding energies for these geometries suggest strong chemisorption of nickel on AlN nano-cage. Moreover, dissociation
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
of Al-N bond is observed concurrent with the formation of Ni-Al and Ni-N bonds when the Ni atom is adsorbed on the nano-cage. The energetic feasibility of Ni adsorption on AlN depends on different factors such as the electron transferring, length of the surrounding bonds of the adsorbed Ni (with Al and N atoms) and their hybridization. Results from the calculations also reveal that there is significant charge transfer from the nano-cage to the metal atom which reduces the Egap (EHOMO-ELUMO). The HOMO-LUMO gap for P4 geometry is 1.79 eV which is much lower than the band gap for pure AlNnano-cage (3.93 eV). The band gap for P1, P2 and P3 geometries is 2.90, 2.79 and 3.18 eV, respectively. The decrease in band gap is attributed to the push of outer d electrons of the transition metals to become more diffuse like. The HOMOs in all geometries have densities on Ni atom whereas the densities in LUMO are distributed on the entire skeleton. The results revealed that Ni adsorption provides N-type conduction which makes it an ideal adsorbent for practical applications in magnetism, catalysis and other areas. Reactivity descriptors indicate an increase in electrophilic character of Ni-adsorbed nano-cages compared to pure AlN nanocage. The electron affinity and softness are highest for P4 geometry whereas the lowest ionization potential and hardness are calculated for P4.
